commit_message:
Remove tox locale overrides

* tox.ini: The LANG, LANGUAGE and LC_ALL environment overrides were
introduced originally during the testr migration in an attempt to be
conservative about the possibility that locale settings in the
calling environment could cause consistency problems for test runs.
In actuality, this should be unnecessary and any place where it does
cause issues ought to be considered an actual bug. Also, having
these in the configuration actively causes older pip to have
problems with non-ASCII content in some package metadata files under
Python 3, so drop it now.

Change-Id: I67479804e02fea28a28a446660c32a412b3ba7c4
Closes-Bug: #1277495

* dhcpv6-stateful
* dhcpv6-stateless
* slaac

In addition to these values, additional behaviors are specified for
when only one of the attributes is set. For example, a Neutron network
that uses a physical router as a gateway, that transmits ICMPv6 Router
Advertisement packets to configure hosts on the network will create
Neutron Subnets that have ipv6_ra_mode *not* set, and ipv6_address_mode
set to 'slaac' so that Neutron will calculate EUI64 addresses for
each port assigned to the subnet, and not spawn a Dnsmasq process.

These attributes maintain backwards compatability with the enable_dhcp
Subnet attribute, by requiring a subnet with these attributes to also
have enable_dhcp set to True.

DocImpact

Implements bp ipv6-two-attributes

commit_message:
Create new IPv6 attributes for Subnets

* Introduces two new optional attributes for Subnets:
  * ipv6_ra_mode
  * ipv6_address_mode

Both attributes accept the following values:

* dhcpv6-stateful
* dhcpv6-stateless
* slaac

In addition to these values, additional behaviors are specified for
when only one of the attributes is set. For example, a Neutron network
that uses a physical router as a gateway, that transmits ICMPv6 Router
Advertisement packets to configure hosts on the network will create
Neutron Subnets that have ipv6_ra_mode *not* set, and ipv6_address_mode
set to 'slaac' so that Neutron will calculate EUI64 addresses for
each port assigned to the subnet, and not spawn a Dnsmasq process.

These attributes maintain backwards compatability with the enable_dhcp
Subnet attribute, by requiring a subnet with these attributes to also
have enable_dhcp set to True.

DocImpact

Implements bp ipv6-two-attributes

commit_message:
Add new command line switch --now

When using --l3-agent-migrate together with --now, neutron-ha-tool will
do the router migration immediately, instead of waiting for some random
amount of time.

Change-Id: I314d2cc5b79091685421813102494e2fcce04768
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-network refs/changes/99/81199/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add kombu driver library to requirements.txt

The RabbitMQ driver is the default driver for oslo.messaging, so it
makes some sense to require this by default. This is consistent with
the way e.g. Nova has always required kombu.

Change-Id: Ibcab58e3f3edce794b571cfabc0a5bcf96c9b47e
Closes-Bug: #1288425

commit_message:
Add group permission for /etc/nova directory

Having a service program need to access /etc/nova/nova.conf file,
although the service program's service user has been added into the
"nova" service user, because /etc/nova folder permission has been set to
700 in nova-common recipe, thus the service program can not start. From
openstack-block-storage cookbook, it sets the /etc/cinder directly
permission as 750, I would think it's reasonable to grant the group
access to /etc/nova directory.

Closes-Bug: #1293956
Change-Id: I6d3ee5c424756fe11cefd425a3dddd3595b025d8

commit_message:
Add a single attribute for qpid protocol

This fixes the issue that there is no single attribute for qpid protocol
attribute, I defined a ['openstack']['mq']['qpid']['protocol']
attribute and it's default value is "tcp", and for the various openstack
service's qpid protocol attribute, we can override this attribute for
all openstack service, or they can override the individual qpid protocol
for the specific openstack service

Change-Id: I4cdae33f9d3f83edbf62d5019f9cb6830a02ab83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-common refs/changes/57/81157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: protocol: 'tcp',

commit_message:
Add ability to specify IP for service

The problem that this change addresses is that the address_for method
will not work correctly if there are multiple IP address associated
with the specified interface.

The approach to solving this problem and moving towards the overall
goal of having one place where service networking information is
stored is to convert address_for calls into endpoints, and add a
address() method to the endpoints interface for IP address resolution.

The address() method has the following behavior: if the
bind_interface of an endpoint is set, then the IP is looked up on
the interface.  Otherwise, the IP specified in the host attribute is
returned.  This allows the caller to choose either method of
determining what IP a service will be bound to.

This change switches the identity cookbook to use an endpoint for
binding instead of address_for.

This change is dependent on the follow change which adds the endpoint
to common:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/79387/

blueprint increase-ip-binding-flexibility

Change-Id: Ibccc187c5b04e78468d289d175407007451a4b2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-identity refs/changes/19/78019/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bind_endpoint = endpoint 'identity-bind'bind_address = bind_endpoint.host
deleted_lines: if node['openstack']['identity']['bind_interface'].nil? bind_address = identity_endpoint.host else bind_address = address_for node['openstack']['identity']['bind_interface'] end

Python3: do not use contextlib.nested()

Use the "mock.patch.object" decorators instead: they are compatible with Python
2.6, 2.7 and 3.3.

Change-Id: Iba053caef0d8095f8df74fbf9a59059093bc06e8

commit_message:
Adds Hostnames for OSO Instances

Previously, the OSO broker/node instances would get spawned
using a combination of stack name, nova instance name and UUID.

This patch allows a user to specify a hostname for broker and
node instances.  It makes working with broker/node instances
much easier from a user's perspective.

Change-Id: Ib077acb257e5add6c36b4a913cc6752c716524a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/38/78438/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "BrokerHostname": { "Description": "Hostname of Broker instance", "Type": "String", "Default": "openshift.brokerinstance.novalocal", "MinLength": "1" }, "NodeHostname": { "Description": "Hostname of Node instance", "Type": "String", "Default": "openshift.nodeinstance.novalocal", "MinLength": "1" }, "export HOSTNAME=", { "Ref": "BrokerHostname"}, "\n", "export HOSTNAME=", { "Ref": "NodeHostname"}, "\n",
deleted_lines: "export HOSTNAME=\"`facter hostname`\"\n", "export HOSTNAME=\"`facter hostname`\"\n",

subject: Fixes Neutron Security Rules for Mcollective Communication
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-06 19:05:14.000000000', 'files': ['openshift-origin/F19/OpenShift.template'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates/commit/5d8830bcbad8deacd3f36fc37ea60612377b543f', 'message': 'Fixes Neutron Security Rules for Mcollective Communication

Previously, neutron security rules were incorrectly specified
to allow ActiveMQ TCP ports.  This was not previously observed
since a single OpenStack Compute Host was used to run Broker and
Node instances. Additionally, duplicate entries for ActiveMQ
TCP port 8161 were specified.  This patch removes the duplicate
entries and changes the TCP port number from ActiveMQ to
Mcollective (61613).

Change-Id: Ia35267a4485bba4aab36b9a629993ab94f42ad11
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes Neutron Security Rules for Mcollective Communication

Previously, neutron security rules were incorrectly specified
to allow ActiveMQ TCP ports.  This was not previously observed
since a single OpenStack Compute Host was used to run Broker and
Node instances. Additionally, duplicate entries for ActiveMQ
TCP port 8161 were specified.  This patch removes the duplicate
entries and changes the TCP port number from ActiveMQ to
Mcollective (61613).

Change-Id: Ia35267a4485bba4aab36b9a629993ab94f42ad11

subject: Changes Neutron Security Group Ports to Integers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-06 18:42:52.000000000', 'files': ['openshift-origin/F19/OpenShift.template'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates/commit/e005415ad49ba47ebc1c77e5f325bb832d3fbc40', 'message': 'Changes Neutron Security Group Ports to Integers

Previously, neutron security group tcp/udp port numbers were
defined as strings.  This was not an issue when testing with trunk
but is an issue when testing with 2014.1.b2.

2014.1.b2 expects the parameters to be defined as integers not
strings.  When the tcp/udp ports are defined as integers, the
security group rules work with trunk as well as 2014.1.b2.

Change-Id: If7e5af163993b4cad3f31583ea73e9e856ab0ccb
'}]
commit_message:
Changes Neutron Security Group Ports to Integers

Previously, neutron security group tcp/udp port numbers were
defined as strings.  This was not an issue when testing with trunk
but is an issue when testing with 2014.1.b2.

2014.1.b2 expects the parameters to be defined as integers not
strings.  When the tcp/udp ports are defined as integers, the
security group rules work with trunk as well as 2014.1.b2.

Change-Id: If7e5af163993b4cad3f31583ea73e9e856ab0ccb

commit_message:
bump version of mysql cookbook in Berksfile

Fixes: bug 1294114

upstream 4.1.1 contains a fix to explicitly create the root@127.0.0.1
user which, as per that bug, is not always happening.

Change-Id: I03156abb44acca61a9c94902363c81314208313d

breaks packaging of the non .py files.

commit_message:
O'Reilly edits on ch_ops_projects_users.xml

Change-Id: I0d01c6a309d5629b52805cf549bbff7efb4d8658
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/03/80803/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To create a project through the OpenStack dashboard: Select the Admin tab in the left navigation bar. You are prompted for a project name and an optional, but recommended, description. Select the check box at the bottom of the form to enable this project. By default, it is enabled, which is shown in Figure 9-1. It is also possible to add project members and adjust the project quotas. We'll discuss those actions later, but in practice it can be quite convenient to deal with all these operations at one time. This command creates a project named "demo." Optionally, you can add a description string by appending --description tenant-description, which can be very useful. You can also create a group in a disabled state by appending --enabled false to the command. By default, projects are created in an enabled state. Typically, default values are changed because a tenant requires more than the OpenStack default of 10 volumes per tenant, or more than the OpenStack default of 1 TB of disk space on a compute node. +----------------------------------+----------+---------++----------------------------------+----------+---------+ OpenStack Havana introduced a basic quota feature for the Image service, so you can now restrict a project's image storage by total number of bytes. Currently, this quota is applied cloud-wide, so if you were to set an Image quota limit of 5 GB, then all projects in your cloud will be able to store only 5 GB of images and snapshots. For example, to restrict a project's image storage to 5 GB, do this: glance-api.conf that limits the number of members allowed per image, called image_member_quota, set to 128 by default. That setting is a different quota from the storage quota. Quota Description Property Name Floating IPs RAM Megabytes of instance RAM allowed per tenant. View and Update Compute Quotas for a Tenant (Project) Container quotas: Limits the total size (in bytes) or number of objects that can be stored in a single container. Account quotas: Limits the total size (in bytes) that a user has available in the Object Storage service. To take advantage of either container quotas or account quotas, your Object Storage proxy server must have container_quotas or account_quotas (or both) added to the [pipeline:main] pipeline. Each quota type also requires its own section in the proxy-server.conf file: To view and update Object Storage quotas, use the swift command provided by the python-swiftclient package. Any user included in the project can view the quotas placed on their project. To update Object Storage quotas on a project, you must have the role of ResellerAdmin in the project that the quota is being applied to. Set Block Storage Quotas View and Update Block Storage Quotas for a Tenant (Project) The command-line tools for managing users are inconvenient to use directly. They require issuing multiple commands to complete a single task, and they use UUIDs rather than symbolic names for many items. In practice, humans typically do not use these tools directly. Fortunately, the OpenStack dashboard provides a reasonable interface to this. In addition, many sites write custom tools for local needs to enforce local policies and provide levels of self-service to users that aren't currently available with packaged tools. Username and email address are self-explanatory, though your site may have local conventions you should observe. Setting and changing passwords in the Identity service requires administrative privileges. As of the Folsom release, users cannot change their own passwords. This is a large driver for creating local custom tools, and must be kept in mind when assigning and distributing passwords. The primary project is simply the first project the user is associated with and must exist prior to creating the user. Role is almost always going to be "member." Out of the box, OpenStack comes with two roles defined: member: a typical user. admin: an administrative super user, which has full permissions across all projects and should be used with great care. Once you've gathered this information, creating the user in the dashboard is just another web form similar to what we've seen before and can be found by clicking the Users link in the Admin navigation bar and then clicking the Create User button at the top right. Modifying users is also done from this Users page. If you have a large number of users, this page can get quite crowded. The Filter search box at the top of the page can be used to limit the users listing. A form very similar to the user creation dialog can be pulled up by selecting Edit from the actions dropdown menu at the end of the line for the user you are modifying. Many sites run with users being associated with only one project. This is a more conservative and simpler choice both for administration and for users. Administratively, if a user reports a problem with an instance or quota, it is obvious which project this relates to as well. Users needn't worry about what project they are acting in if they are only in one project. However, note that, by default, any user can affect the resources of any other user within their project. It is also possible to associate users with multiple projects if that makes sense for your organization. Associating existing users with an additional project or removing them from an older project is done from the Projects page of the dashboard by selecting Modify Users from the Actions column, as shown in Figure 9-2: The first column of this form, named All Users, includes a list of all the users in your cloud who are not already associated with this project. The second column shows all the users who are. These lists can be quite long, but they can be limited by typing a substring of the user name you are looking for in the filter field at the top of the column. The dangerous possibility comes with the ability to change member roles. This is the dropdown list below the user name in the Project Members list. In virtually all cases this value should be set to Member. This example purposefully shows an administrative user where this value is admin.The admin is global not per project, so granting a user the admin role in any project gives the user administrative rights across the whole cloud. Typical use is to only create administrative users in a single project, by convention the admin project, which is created by default during cloud setup. If your administrative users also use the cloud to launch and manage instances, it is strongly recommended that you use separate user accounts for administrative access and normal operations and that they be in distinct projects. The default authorization settings allow administrative users only to create resources on behalf of a different project. OpenStack handles two kind of authorization policies: Operation-based: Policies specify access criteria for specific operations, possibly with fine-grained control over specific attributes. Resource-based: Whether access to a specific resource might be granted or not according to the permissions configured for the resource (currently available only for the network resource). The actual authorization policies enforced in an OpenStack service vary from deployment to deployment. The policy engine reads entries from the policy.json file. The actual location of this file might vary from distribution to distribution: for nova, it is typically in /etc/nova/policy.json. You can update entries while the system is running, and you do not have to restart services. Currently, the only way to update such policies is to edit the policy file. Role-based rules: Evaluate successfully if the user submitting the request has the specified role. For instance "role:admin" is successful if the user submitting the request is an administrator. Field-based rules: Evaluate successfully if a field of the resource specified in the current request matches a specific value. For instance "field:networks:shared=True" is successful if the attribute shared of the network resource is set to true. Generic rules: Compare an attribute in the resource with an attribute extracted from the user's security credentials and evaluates successfully if the comparison is successful. For instance "tenant_id:%(tenant_id)s" is successful if the tenant identifier in the resource is equal to the tenant identifier of the user submitting the request. [1] Shows a rule that evaluates successfully if the current user is an administrator or the owner of the resource specified in the request (tenant identifier is equal). [2] Shows the default policy, which is always evaluated if an API operation does not match any of the policies in policy.json. [3] Shows a policy restricting the ability to manipulate flavors to administrators using the Admin API only. Users Who Disrupt Other Users For example, a group of users have instances that are utilizing a large amount of compute resources for very compute-intensive tasks. This is driving the load up on compute nodes and affecting other users. In this situation, review your user use cases. You may find that high compute scenarios are common, and should then plan for proper segregation in your cloud, such as host aggregation or regions. Another example is a user consuming a very large amount of bandwidth. Again, the key is to understand what the user is doing. If they naturally need a high amount of bandwidth, you might have to limit their transmission rate as to not affect other users or move the user to an area with more bandwidth available. On the other hand, maybe the user's instance has been hacked and is part of a botnet launching DDOS attacks. Resolution of this issue is the same as though any other server on your network has been hacked. Contact the user and give them time to respond. If they don't respond, shut down the instance.

Modifying users is also done from this "Users" page. If you have a large number of users, this page can get quite crowded. The "Filter" search box at the top of the page can be used to limit the users listing. A form very similar to the user creation dialog can be pulled up by selecting "Edit" from the actions drop down menu at the end of the line for the user you are modifying. Many sites run with users being associated with only one project. This is a more conservative and simpler choice both for administration and for users. Administratively if a user reports a problem with an instance or quota it is obvious which project this relates to as well. Users needn't worry about what project they are acting in if they are only in one project. However, note that, by default, any user can affect the resources of any other user within their project. It is also possible to associate users with multiple projects if that makes sense for your organization. Associating existing users with an additional project or removing them from an older project is done from the "Projects" page of the Dashboard by selecting the "Modify Users" from the "Actions" column: Edit Project Members tab of the dashboard, from which you can perform actions on users. The first column of this form, titled "All Users", will include a list of all the users in your cloud who are not already associated with this project and the second all the users who are. These can be quite long, but can be limited by typing a substring of the user name you are looking for in the filter field at the top of the column. The dangerous possibility comes in the ability to change member roles. This is the drop down list after the user name in the Project Members list. In virtually all cases this value should be set to "Member". This example purposefully show and administrative user where this value is "admin".The "admin" is global not per project so granting a user the admin role in any project gives the administrative rights across the whole cloud. Typical use is to only create administrative users in a single project, by convention the "admin" project which is created by default during cloud setup. If your administrative users also use the cloud to launch and manage instances it is strongly recommended that you use separate user accounts for administrative access and normal operations and that they be in distinct projects. The default authorization settings only allow administrative users to create resources on behalf of a different project. OpenStack handles two kind of authorization policies: Operation-based: policies specify access criteria for specific operations, possibly with fine-grained control over specific attributes. Resource-based: whether access to a specific resource might be granted or not according to the permissions configured for the resource (currently available only for the network resource). The actual authorization policies enforced in an OpenStack service vary from deployment to deployment. The policy engine reads entries from the policy.json file. The actual location of this file might vary from distribution to distribution, for nova it is typically in /etc/nova/policy.json. You can update entries while the system is running, and you do not have to restart services. Currently the only way to update such policies is to edit the policy file. Role-based rules: evaluate successfully if the user submitting the request has the specified role. For instance "role:admin"is successful if the user submitting the request is an administrator. Field-based rules: evaluate successfully if a field of the resource specified in the current request matches a specific value. For instance "field:networks:shared=True" is successful if the attribute shared of the network resource is set to true. Generic rules: compare an attribute in the resource with an attribute extracted from the user's security credentials and evaluates successfully if the comparison is successful. For instance "tenant_id:%(tenant_id)s" is successful if the tenant identifier in the resource is equal to the tenant identifier of the user submitting the request. [1] Shows a rule which evaluates successfully if the current user is an administrator or the owner of the resource specified in the request (tenant identifier is equal). [2] Shows the default policy which is always evaluated if an API operation does not match any of the policies in policy.json. [3] Shows a policy restricting the ability of manipulating flavors to administrators using the Admin API only. Users that Disrupt Other Users For example: A group of users have instances that are utilizing a large amount of compute resources for very compute-intensive tasks. This is driving the load up on compute nodes and affecting other users. In this situation, review your user use cases. You may find that high compute scenarios are common and should then plan for proper segregation in your cloud such as host aggregation or regions. Another example is a user consuming a very large amount of bandwidth. Again, the key is to understand what the user is doing. If they naturally need a high amount of bandwidth, you might have to limit their transmission rate as to not affect other users or move them to an area with more bandwidth available. On the other hand, maybe the user's instance has been hacked and is part of a botnet launching DDOS attacks. Resolution to this issue is the same as if any other server on your network has been hacked. Contact the user and give them time to respond. If they don't respond, shut the instance down.

commit_message:
Fix image service endpoint spec

After converging with telemetry and image, the ceilometer meters and
resources for glance do not appear, the logs show that the glance API
URL is incorrect: http://127.0.0.1:9292/v2/v1.

The openstack-common cookbook was updated to set the right path but we
need to update the test cases.

Change-Id: I656e133995b4cbad12540d03c97adf1164b0f4c5
Closes-Bug: #1293688

commit_message:
Correct swift proxy service name

Swift proxy service is named swift-proxy on ubuntu distribution, and
openstack-swift-proxy on suse and redhat. But there are some places
use incorrect name for service operations, they should be fixed.

Change-Id: I784e2c290833592cda7e1a2de737787fd739baee
Closes-Bug: #1293901
Closes-Bug: #1293907
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit d29fba92ba1ad087621e56b4171165c7952b1626)

subject: Dispose db connections pool on disconnect
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-18 10:59:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/5ee720de143cca113078ab1549451ba81f3e021f', 'message': 'Dispose db connections pool on disconnect

When a disconnect happens (e.g. when VIP moves to another node), all
existing connections in the pool become invalid. There is no sense to
check every single connection in the pool, as this may take a long
time (e.g. when python-mysqldb driver is used with eventlet green
threads, there is no context switch on db IO, so the whole process is
blocked until socket read times out). Dispose all connections in the
pool when disconnect is detected, they will be recreated on demand
then.

Closes-Bug: #1288438

Change-Id: Ia357da2b3092d306a86b6d1787bab374a335f28c
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-18 15:47:20.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/db/sqlalchemy/test_sqlalchemy.py', 'openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/session.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/5b7e61c82f95187691000b4749ed8307df0766da', 'message': 'Dispose db connections pool on disconnect

When a disconnect happens (e.g. when VIP moves to another node), all
existing connections in the pool become invalid. There is no sense to
check every single connection in the pool, as this may take a long
time (e.g. when python-mysqldb driver is used with eventlet green
threads, there is no context switch on db IO, so the whole process is
blocked until socket read times out). Dispose all connections in the
pool when disconnect is detected, they will be recreated on demand
then.

Closes-Bug: #1288438

Change-Id: Ia357da2b3092d306a86b6d1787bab374a335f28c
'}]
commit_message:
Dispose db connections pool on disconnect

When a disconnect happens (e.g. when VIP moves to another node), all
existing connections in the pool become invalid. There is no sense to
check every single connection in the pool, as this may take a long
time (e.g. when python-mysqldb driver is used with eventlet green
threads, there is no context switch on db IO, so the whole process is
blocked until socket read times out). Dispose all connections in the
pool when disconnect is detected, they will be recreated on demand
then.

Closes-Bug: #1288438

Change-Id: Ia357da2b3092d306a86b6d1787bab374a335f28c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/25/81225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if the database server has hone away, all connections in the pool # have become invalid and we can safely close all of them here, # rather than waste time on checking of every single connection engine.dispose() # this will be handled by SQLAlchemy and will force it to create # a new connection and retry the original action

commit_message:
Archive tempest.conf safely as tempest_conf.txt

* functions.sh(cleanup_host): Instead of renaming tempest.conf to
tempest.conf.txt and then immediately deleting it because it matches
the *.*.txt glob, use tempest_conf.txt instead.

Change-Id: I255a7472ce07b1fedfd15a50fa8d80a24a79f368
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/40/81140/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo cp $BASE/old/tempest/etc/tempest.conf $BASE/logs/old/tempest_conf.txt sudo cp $BASE/new/tempest/etc/tempest.conf $NEWLOGTARGET/tempest_conf.txt
deleted_lines: sudo cp $BASE/old/tempest/etc/tempest.conf $BASE/logs/old/tempest.conf.txt sudo cp $BASE/new/tempest/etc/tempest.conf $NEWLOGTARGET/tempest.conf.txt

commit_message:
Change the 'savanna-db' scheme to 'internal-db'

The url scheme indicating internal store for job binaries has
been changed from 'savanna-db' to 'internal-db'. All of the constant
strings in the code referencing 'savanna-db' have been changed.

Partial-Implements: blueprint savanna-renaming-service
Change-Id: I94baab611570679bfff817bde2e5400a63d364ca

subject: NSX: Ensure gateway devices are usable after upgrade
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-17 14:52:59.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/19180cf98af6_nsx_gw_devices.py', 'neutron/plugins/vmware/nsxlib/l2gateway.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fb5bef8f53e80c1cbd7e570d26651723d4ff599c', 'message': 'NSX: Ensure gateway devices are usable after upgrade

The gateway device database migration upon an upgrade creates
gateway devices objects from references in network gateway
objects.
While these gateway devices are perfectly usable
in network gateways, they are not directly visible to tenants
and also cannot be updated to change details such as name,
connector type or ip as well as the client certificate.

This patch fixes the DB migration in order to ensure tenant
have access to gateway devices created after an upgrade.
This patch also modifies the l2 gateway nsxlib module to
ensure request bodies are correctly created even when not all
the attributes of a gateway device are specified.

Change-Id: I7077e9884adc739fb75e64a6e9a17a124d79fb6b
Closes-Bug: 1293617
'}]
commit_message:
NSX: Ensure gateway devices are usable after upgrade

The gateway device database migration upon an upgrade creates
gateway devices objects from references in network gateway
objects.
While these gateway devices are perfectly usable
in network gateways, they are not directly visible to tenants
and also cannot be updated to change details such as name,
connector type or ip as well as the client certificate.

This patch fixes the DB migration in order to ensure tenant
have access to gateway devices created after an upgrade.
This patch also modifies the l2 gateway nsxlib module to
ensure request bodies are correctly created even when not all
the attributes of a gateway device are specified.

Change-Id: I7077e9884adc739fb75e64a6e9a17a124d79fb6b
Closes-Bug: 1293617
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/89/80989/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: nsx_connector_type = connector_type_mappings[connector_type] "transport_connectors": [ {"transport_zone_uuid": tz_uuid, "ip_address": connector_ip, "type": nsx_connector_type}],

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-14 16:51:58.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/compute/v3/servers/test_create_server.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/d5c2e24108badc95448bbff72fcda60391192e15', 'message': 'Remove test_can_log_into_created_server

test_can_log_into_created_server, and referencing to not existing
method.

Does not makes sense just testing the login alone, if we have lot of test
for testing many other ssh dependent things.
A basic remote command execution cost is close to just trying

Change-Id: I0d53727934249f83cc562ab8e372aaffb4b1ac65
Implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy

commit_message:
Remove test_can_log_into_created_server

The nova v3 version of test_create_server still has the
test_can_log_into_created_server, and referencing to not existing
method.

Does not makes sense just testing the login alone, if we have lot of test
for testing many other ssh dependent things.
A basic remote command execution cost is close to just trying
to authenticate.

Change-Id: I0d53727934249f83cc562ab8e372aaffb4b1ac65
Implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/29/80629/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def test_can_log_into_created_server(self): # Check that the user can authenticate with the generated password linux_client = remote_client.RemoteClient(self.server, self.ssh_user, self.password) self.assertTrue(linux_client.can_authenticate()) @testtools.skipIf(not run_ssh, 'Instance validation tests are disabled.') @test.attr(type='gate')

commit_message:
os-*-config package install support

Package install support for:
* os-collect-config
* os-refresh-config
* os-apply-config

This change requires a corresponding change to dib to move the install
type enablement out of source-repositories since the os-*-config
packages do not use source-repositories:
cccdcb904d485fce92443edbb088740e074c3046

Change-Id: I22672a4312152ab594de2a149e16866c7564e3d4

commit_message:
fix(gate): one for pypy, one for docs

Drop the version requirement for setuptools w/ tox:pypy to workaround:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ci/+bug/1290562

Also add in sphinx-reqs to make the docs gate happy.

Change-Id: I5ac510373809733129401b51ad39579d2963fab2

commit_message:
Added Cmode driver

Added new module NetAppClusteredShareDriver.
Implements bp add-netapp-clustered-share-driver

Change-Id: Ia35445d77f69e9a17560543fdbe1faa1db85b326
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/00/59100/49 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parent_snapshot_name = self._get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id']) snapshot_name = self._get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id']) snapshot_name = self._get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id']) def _check_response(request, response): """Checks RPC responses from NetApp devices.""" if response.Status == 'failed': name = request.Name reason = response.Reason msg = _('API %(name)s failed: %(reason)s') raise exception.Error(msg % locals()) def _get_valid_share_name(share_id): """The name can contain letters, numbers, and the underscore character (_). The first character must be a letter or an underscore.""" return 'share_' + share_id.replace('-', '_') def _get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot_id): """The name can contain letters, numbers, and the underscore character (_). The first character must be a letter or an underscore.""" return 'share_snapshot_' + snapshot_id.replace('-', '_') valid_share_name = self._get_valid_share_name(share['id']) share_name = self._get_valid_share_name(share['id']) share_name = '/vol/' + self._get_valid_share_name(share['id'])
deleted_lines: parent_snapshot_name = _get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id']) snapshot_name = _get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id']) snapshot_name = _get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot['id'])def _check_response(request, response): """Checks RPC responses from NetApp devices.""" if response.Status == 'failed': name = request.Name reason = response.Reason msg = _('API %(name)s failed: %(reason)s') raise exception.Error(msg % locals()) def _get_valid_share_name(share_id): """The name can contain letters, numbers, and the underscore character (_). The first character must be a letter or an underscore.""" return 'share_' + share_id.replace('-', '_') def _get_valid_snapshot_name(snapshot_id): """The name can contain letters, numbers, and the underscore character (_). The first character must be a letter or an underscore.""" return 'share_snapshot_' + snapshot_id.replace('-', '_') valid_share_name = _get_valid_share_name(share['id']) share_name = _get_valid_share_name(share['id']) share_name = '/vol/' + _get_valid_share_name(share['id'])

commit_message:
Add space before GB/TB

Add in all cases a space between number and GB/TB.
No change was needed for KB/MB.

Change-Id: Ie889b7273b5259e665e6b41165ff9f40bfcd41fc

commit_message:
Return the thread created in consume_in_thread

Returns the thread created so that the caller can manage it.

Change-Id: If9685a8ddc95b5db179ff8a10ec0ca5fd62ffbed
Closes-Bug: #1293650
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/09/81009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.connection.consume_in_thread()

added_lines: Before You Download and Install Fuel ==================================== Before downloading and installing Fuel: - Be sure that you your hardware configuration is adequate; check the `Prerequisites information <http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel/fuel-4.1/install-guide.html#prerequisites>`_. - Understand the networking architecture and define your networking configuraion; see `Understanding and Configuring the Network <http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel/fuel-4.1/install-guide.html#understanding-and-configuring-the-network>`_ and `Network Architecture <http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel/fuel-4.0/reference-architecture.html#network-architecture>`_. Downloading the installable image ================================= 1. Go to the `Mirantis Software Download Page <http://software.mirantis.com/>`_ and fill out the information to opt in to the Mirantis community. 2. You should receive a response from Mirantis within the hour; this mail includes credential you can use to download Fuel. If you do not receive the acknowledgement from Mirantis, write to to: sw-access@mirantis.com. Use as a file to install the virtualized deployment; cut to DVD to install Fuel on bare-metal. Cut to a USB flash media device that can be used to to install Fuel on bare-metal. Both installation images contain the installer for Fuel Master node.
deleted_lines: Downloading Fuel ================ Before installation, download the installation image from the `Mirantis web-site <http://fuel.mirantis.com/redirect-page/>`_. .. note:: You must sign in to download the Fuel image. Fuel supports the following OpenStack releases: * **Grizzly** Fuel Master node, CentOS & Ubuntu operating systems for deployment as an OpenStack nodes’ host OS, and the Mirantis OpenStack hardened packages. For installation from CD media devices. For installation from flash media devices (USB). Both installation images contain the installer for Fuel Master node.

commit_message:
PXE validate() to fail if no Ironic API URL

As part of the deploy process the conductor should pass the URL of the
Ironic API to the deploy ramdisk so that it can talk back to the Ironic
API, but if the URL is not present in the Ironic configuration file or
in the keystone catalog the deploy process will fail in the middle. This
patch adds a verification to the validate() method to make sure the URL
is present before the deploy starts.

Related-Bug: #1290482
Change-Id: I95472660deff0e23a19d0b744f711bbe3acc2191
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/79/79579/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient import exceptions as ksexceptionfrom ironic.common import keystone self.config(group='conductor', api_url='http://127.0.0.1:1234/') @mock.patch.object(keystone, 'get_service_url') def test_validate_good_api_url_from_config_file(self, mock_ks): # not present in the keystone catalog mock_ks.side_effect = ksexception.EndpointNotFound with task_manager.acquire(self.context, [self.node['uuid']], shared=True) as task: task.resources[0].driver.deploy.validate(task, self.node) @mock.patch.object(keystone, 'get_service_url') def test_validate_good_api_url_from_keystone(self, mock_ks): # present in the keystone catalog mock_ks.return_value = 'http://127.0.0.1:1234' # not present in the config file self.config(group='conductor', api_url=None) with task_manager.acquire(self.context, [self.node['uuid']], shared=True) as task: task.resources[0].driver.deploy.validate(task, self.node) @mock.patch.object(keystone, 'get_service_url') def test_validate_fail_no_api_url(self, mock_ks): # not present in the keystone catalog mock_ks.side_effect = ksexception.EndpointNotFound # not present in the config file self.config(group='conductor', api_url=None) with task_manager.acquire(self.context, [self.node['uuid']], shared=True) as task: self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameterValue, task.resources[0].driver.deploy.validate, task, self.node)

commit_message:
add persistence of anchors

It used to be that in jumping between different log levels you
would loose the timestamp anchor that you set. We can fix that
with javascript so that you can set an anchor which is persisted
on the selectors. Then you can jump between different log levels
and not lose your place.

Change-Id: Idf7d204fbff558e3e43e152f601895c5c8567039

commit_message:
highlighting the way you expect

This provides highlighting in os-loganalyze the way you expect.
When an url with a # is passed in, the lines matching that class
are highlighted. If you click on a date the highlight is changed
to that class block.

Change-Id: I23776d70ae2bf1f65aac3761f2e43521a68f88df

commit_message:
provide a -e run target to run server locally

this makes it much easier to see things in action, but running
the whole stack locally based on the sample files we provide in
the tree.

Change-Id: Ia27f81a87b116f5b8d6efad75fb6ed33868964ef

commit_message:
Make sure auth_url exists and is not versionless

When getting the Ironic API service URL from the Keystone catalog make
sure that the Keystone API endpoint is present and that it contains the
right version of the API.

Closes-Bug: #1290482
Change-Id: I80fc74a1aea02074baba4839df83e0e694bc8ea6

commit_message:
Add +x to executable files

There are a few in the tree that don't have it and should.  This
will allow future enforcement of this to avoid files being
committed with the wrong mode set.

Change-Id: Ie22a663a230f087b678c01a16219e1c5b7e237c0

commit_message:
Fix flake8 failures

Right now tox -e pep8 in this project fails due to some violations
in the tempest element.  Those will need to be fixed before we can
do any gating on pep8-type tests.

Change-Id: I8c63e9db4e86ef6209ef7676ee0c5ca289845f96

Ensure a default value for DEVTEST_PERF_COMMENT

This prevents exiting with an error at the end of devtest.sh if the
variable is not set.

commit_message:
ensure log_file is absent when using syslog

When using syslog, we don't need to write in keystone.log file, so
log_file param should be absent to avoid any write in the file.

Example: run keystone-manage db_sync will write in ~/keystone.log
instead of /var/log/syslog.

Closes-bug #1292619
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
Change-Id: I9b2613294625f3df27a70f45bd964688a425c88e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/33/80633/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'DEFAULT/use_syslog': value => true; 'DEFAULT/syslog_log_facility': value => $log_facility; 'DEFAULT/log_file': ensure => absent;
deleted_lines: 'DEFAULT/use_syslog': value => true; 'DEFAULT/syslog_log_facility': value => $log_facility;

commit_message:
Relax regex when keystone refuses connections

Seems newer python-keystoneclient have a different excpetion message,
specifically they dropped the HTTP prefix.  Now we allow both messages to be
trapped.

Add some additional cases that are common regex now covers
 (HTTP 400)
 [Errno 111] Connection refused
 503 Service Unavailable
 Max retries exceeded
 HTTP Unable to establish connection
 Unable to establish connection to http://...

Change-Id: I71fada12b3dbb681288c7ef2891603f970910736
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>
Signed-off-by: Andrew Woodward <awoodward@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/33/80433/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ['[Errno 111] Connection refused', '(HTTP 400)', 'HTTP Unable to establish connection', 'Unable to extablish connection'].reverse.each do |valid_message|
deleted_lines: ['[Errno 111] Connection refused', '(HTTP 400)', 'HTTP Unable to establish connection'].reverse.each do |valid_message|

commit_message:
Some adjustements in language_pack table and db model

- Rename column language_impl to language_implementation to match
  the attribute name in API
- Drop unused column "type"
- Add column language_pack_type

commit_message:
Change deploy validation exception handling

Calls to the deploy validate() method may throw an InvalidParameterValue
exception during node deploy or node tear down. It's more logical to catch
this and throw an InstanceDeployFailure exception instead.

This addresses comments raised during review of change ID
Ic3107a9af6afeb2a9e772ca0ce0acc45dbc182cb.

The test_do_node_deploy_validate_fail and test_do_node_tear_down_validate_fail
tests intentionally still have their mocked object raise the
InvalidParameterValue exception to test that it gets transformed into
an InstanceDeployFailure exception.

Change-Id: I754884d1a012a9e67d2cc7a74e3121e0e02e76ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/71/80671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

" "Error: %(msg)s") % {'msg': e}) "RPC do_node_tear_down " try: task.driver.deploy.validate(task, node) except exception.InvalidParameterValue as e: raise exception.InstanceDeployFailure(_( "RCP do_node_tear_down failed to validate deploy info. " "Error: %(msg)s") % {'msg': e})

commit_message:
Fixed  searching by-path and by-id links for cciss

The problem was that we try to find by-path and by-id
links comparing them with cciss!c0d0 instead of cciss/c0d0.

Change-Id: I2ba76ff615cd94dfef8a275779a1fb917ec70150
Closes-Bug: #1291692

commit_message:
Enable network verification on neutron deployments

Current implementation correctly verifies connectivity
of underlay network, no matter what bridge is used on
target nodes.

It does not checks ovs or bonding functionality,
which i think should be addressed by another check.

Related to blueprint network-checker-neutron-vlan

Change-Id: I78e279b26c9477739d5dacaa61b39bd3c260b87c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/52/78152/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Dont spawn vlan-tagged ifaces on slave nodes with net check

To generate tagged traffic between fuel slave nodes
we dont need to create tagged interfaces.
Insteed we just can add 8021q tag with specified vlan.

In such case we can run net_check with 3000 vlans in 2 mins.
Tested on 2 nodes setup.

Also it makes possible to run net_check for neutron
with vlan type segmentation.

Change-Id: I638845a21067db954c4876aef19034b2317676ff

commit_message:
Move the savanna subdir to sahara

Rename the subdirectory and replace all instances
of "import savanna" with "import sahara" and all
instances of "from savanna" with "from sahara".

* Replaced mock patches like mock.patch('savanna...
* Updated config generator script
* Renamed entry points in setup.cfg
* Hacking checks also fixed
* Manual renaming in alembic scripts to force work migrations
* Fix doc building
* Renamed itests directories
* Some changes in gitignore
* Removed locale dir after rebase

Co-Authored-By: Alexander Ignatov <aignatov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ia77252c24046c3e7283c0a7b96d11636020b949c
Partially implements: blueprint savanna-renaming-service

commit_message:
add parameter for endpoint protocols

This gives the ability to specify https endpoint for
internal and/or admin endpoints.

Change-Id: I9cc1525449ffd9b1439e6e5fcbf6731b8a7ee260
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit 414c7ecec660103f6bcb29c8e99752ce7952a3b2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/18/80918/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*public_protocol*]# [*internal_protocol*] # Protocol for internal endpoint. Optional. Defaults to 'http'. # # [*admin_protocol*] # Protocol for admin endpoint. Optional. Defaults to 'http'. # $public_protocol = 'http', $admin_protocol = 'http', $internal_protocol = 'http' admin_url => "${admin_protocol}://${admin_address}:${port}/${volume_version}/%(tenant_id)s", internal_url => "${internal_protocol}://${internal_address}:${port}/${volume_version}/%(tenant_id)s",
deleted_lines: # [*protocol*] $public_protocol = 'http' admin_url => "http://${admin_address}:${port}/${volume_version}/%(tenant_id)s", internal_url => "http://${internal_address}:${port}/${volume_version}/%(tenant_id)s",

commit_message:
protect dhcp ports flag support

Add a param to the configuration file of the dhcp
agent. With this new param as true iptables rules
are inserted to protect the dnsmasq againts external
requests.

Patch in Neutron: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/61994

Change-Id: Ibf13f96f667fe662b15204b54a544f3375bcfb37
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/97/61997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*dhcp_enable_isolation*] # (optional) Protect the dnsmasq port against external requests, useful in the # case of an external network. # Defaults to false. # $package_ensure = present, $enabled = true, $debug = false, $state_path = '/var/lib/neutron', $resync_interval = 30, $interface_driver = 'neutron.agent.linux.interface.OVSInterfaceDriver', $dhcp_driver = 'neutron.agent.linux.dhcp.Dnsmasq', $root_helper = 'sudo neutron-rootwrap /etc/neutron/rootwrap.conf', $use_namespaces = true, $dhcp_enable_isolation = false 'DEFAULT/debug': value => $debug; 'DEFAULT/state_path': value => $state_path; 'DEFAULT/resync_interval': value => $resync_interval; 'DEFAULT/interface_driver': value => $interface_driver; 'DEFAULT/dhcp_driver': value => $dhcp_driver; 'DEFAULT/use_namespaces': value => $use_namespaces; 'DEFAULT/root_helper': value => $root_helper; 'DEFAULT/dhcp_enable_isolation': value => $dhcp_enable_isolation;
deleted_lines: $package_ensure = present, $enabled = true, $debug = false, $state_path = '/var/lib/neutron', $resync_interval = 30, $interface_driver = 'neutron.agent.linux.interface.OVSInterfaceDriver', $dhcp_driver = 'neutron.agent.linux.dhcp.Dnsmasq', $root_helper = 'sudo neutron-rootwrap /etc/neutron/rootwrap.conf', $use_namespaces = true 'DEFAULT/debug': value => $debug; 'DEFAULT/state_path': value => $state_path; 'DEFAULT/resync_interval': value => $resync_interval; 'DEFAULT/interface_driver': value => $interface_driver; 'DEFAULT/dhcp_driver': value => $dhcp_driver; 'DEFAULT/use_namespaces': value => $use_namespaces; 'DEFAULT/root_helper': value => $root_helper;

commit_message:
Add support for copy offload, E-Series driver

This change adds support in puppet-cinder for the Cinder driver for
NetApp's E-Series storage solutions. It also includes support for the
new copy offload function. Both of these functions were introduced in
the Icehouse release.

Change-Id: I8a718ba19bcf9f558ddf6c96d7f19f2cf8c3e608
Closes-Bug: 1289032
(cherry picked from commit 5f9964815ba4f5fdc7ea107f67a2a2cff2ba0aa8)

commit_message:
Add quota_set delete test for Nova v3 API

This patch adds tests for quota_set API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api-tests

Change-Id: If89b8fd4afbe496a4609694123a480e7f045127d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/37/76737/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test.attr(type='gate') def test_delete_quota(self): # Admin can delete the resource quota set for a tenant tenant_name = data_utils.rand_name('cpu_quota_tenant_') tenant_desc = tenant_name + '-desc' identity_client = self.os_adm.identity_client _, tenant = identity_client.create_tenant(name=tenant_name, description=tenant_desc) tenant_id = tenant['id'] self.addCleanup(identity_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) resp, quota_set_default = self.adm_client.get_quota_set(tenant_id) ram_default = quota_set_default['ram'] self.adm_client.update_quota_set(tenant_id, ram='5120') self.adm_client.delete_quota_set(tenant_id) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) resp, quota_set_new = self.adm_client.get_quota_set(tenant_id) self.assertEqual(ram_default, quota_set_new['ram'])

commit_message:
(WIP) Adds solum-builder-worker

Builder-worker is a separate process from builder,
designed to allow builder to accept requests, queue jobs,
and respond to the requests.

The work of calling the (currently subprocess-based) build
scripts and updating the build's status is to be done by
builder-worker.

(WIP) The presense of the hello function and tool is purely illustrative
and won't be in the final commit. It's to aid in parallel development
of a couple similar RPC services others will be adding.

Change-Id: If030bed793e59bd5c8f131f7ba260986d1f9ba3e

commit_message:
Removal of test .conf files

The following configuration files used for testing purposes have
been migrated to use the configuration fixture instead of relying
on a mechanism to load a large number of configuration options
from various locations on disk.

    keystone/tests/auth_plugin_external_default_legacy.conf
    keystone/tests/auth_plugin_external_disabled.conf
    keystone/tests/auth_plugin_external_domain.conf
    keystone/tests/auth_plugin_external_domain_legacy.conf
    keystone/tests/backend_rules.conf
    keystone/tests/test_associate_project_endpoint_extension.conf
    keystone/tests/test_auth_plugin_by_class_name.conf
    keystone/tests/test_overrides.conf
    keystone/tests/test_pki_token_provider.conf
    keystone/tests/test_revoke_kvs.conf
    keystone/tests/test_revoke_sql.conf
    keystone/tests/test_uuid_token_provider.conf

The following configuration files have had a number of elements
extracted to be used within the config fixture instead of the
configuration files. Most of these files contain controls that
need to be overridden to test against alternative (non internal /
in-memory) "live" configurations.

   keystone/tests/backend_ldap.conf
   keystone/tests/backend_liveldap.conf
   keystone/tests/backend_multi_ldap_sql.conf
   keystone/tests/backend_sql.conf
   keystone/tests/backend_tls_liveldap.conf

This patchset also consolidates the setting of the default
[database] ``connection`` option so that it can be overridden
as needed for testing against non-sqlite database engines.

Change-Id: I996709546f713c36bf654c5aea64cbf3472ffef1

commit_message:
Update stack.sh to use openstackclient commands

There were a few instances of keystoneclient still being used,
these were replaced with their openstackclient equivalent.

Change-Id: I47fb7cf949b9ab054b97ae387ecbc6d7070fa9c3

commit_message:
Remove quota-classes commands

Remove the quota-classes functinality due to this feature has been
removed from nova in change I1110022d6f628d03aaf363da707f2d2ef1600437
and it is returning a HTTP 404 when is executed either a "nova quota-
class-show" or "nova quota-class-update".

This applies for v1_1 and v3.

Partial-Bug: #1292589
Change-Id: Ia6e17e0f7506829b78cc6da53ebba73984e414f4

commit_message:
Treat failure to hear back from neutron as non fatal

A recent change to nova requires neutron to have admin credentials in
order to report back to nova that VIF plugging is complete. Our neutron
doesn't have the appropriate credentials and adding them isn't trivial
as we don't know the tenant id when we do the heat stack-create of the
overcloud.

This commit should be considered a temporary workaround that disables the
requirement, this will unblock ci while we figure out how to handle the
problem correctly.

Related-Bug: #1293782

Change-Id: I1a31d31e3d3ab923217eaf3b2e865a28dd57ec44
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/24/81224/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
multi-backend: configure default type

This patch aims to
- configure a default type in cinder-volume (without it, a volume can't
  boot without explicitly specifying a type from the client, which could
lead to errors)
- add unit tests for cinder::backends class

Change-Id: Ia0a475a629576596dd60e513bf0764e9bc3000ab
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/78/80978/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*default_volume_type*] # (required) default volume type to use. # This should contain the name of the default volume type to use. # If not configured, it produces an error when creating a volume # without specifying a type. # $enabled_backends = undef, $default_volume_type = undef 'DEFAULT/default_volume_type': value => $default_volume_type; } }
deleted_lines: $enabled_backends = undef } }

commit_message:
add parameter for endpoint protocols

This gives the ability to specify https endpoint for
internal and/or admin endpoints.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Icf7cd49c7e7a99b873b861bff51a1317a563f2be
(cherry picked from commit 82e992e64b5fc4365d01fa5950e0d084ae017644)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/17/80917/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*admin_protocol*] # Protocol for admin endpoint. Defaults to 'http'. ## [*internal_protocol*] # Protocol for internal endpoint. Defaults to 'http'. # $admin_protocol = 'http', $internal_protocol = 'http', internal_url => "${internal_protocol}://${internal_address}:${port}/", admin_url => "${admin_protocol}://${admin_address}:${port}/",
deleted_lines: internal_url => "http://${internal_address}:${port}/", admin_url => "http://${admin_address}:${port}/",

commit_message:
Test storage with memory and sqlite backends

While testing storage with all available persistence backends
looks like overkill (they have their own unit tests which should
be enough), adding second backend to test against worth it.

Change-Id: I0c4495f7868b302a80f14bcb55d76a44d8b9a0d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/53/80553/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from taskflow.persistence import backendsclass StorageTestMixin(object): def setUp(self): super(StorageTestMixin, self).setUp() self.backend = None super(StorageTestMixin, self).tearDown() class StorageMemoryTest(StorageTestMixin, test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(StorageMemoryTest, self).setUp() self.backend = backends.fetch({'connection': 'memory://'}) class StorageSQLTest(StorageTestMixin, test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(StorageSQLTest, self).setUp() self.backend = backends.fetch({'connection': 'sqlite://'}) with contextlib.closing(self.backend.get_connection()) as conn: conn.upgrade()
deleted_lines: from taskflow.persistence.backends import impl_memoryclass StorageTest(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(StorageTest, self).setUp() self.backend = impl_memory.MemoryBackend(conf={}) super(StorageTest, self).tearDown()

Return migration list as an array

Python nova client expect an array to be returned from nova
in order to correctly format the result

layout and markup in the Upgrades chapter of the ops guide.

subject: Fix executor requests publishing bug
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-18 12:09:52.000000000', 'files': ['taskflow/engines/worker_based/executor.py', 'taskflow/tests/unit/worker_based/test_executor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/670be83b56b745c0bda437fc4e1c6b88defee4d0', 'message': "Fix executor requests publishing bug

Make sure request is set to the PENDING state before putting
it into the requests cache to prevent the notify processing
thread get list of waiting requests and publish it before it
is published in the executor thread. So request wouldn't be
published twice.

Change-Id: If6f39a82c5b8554cd429f9ad342021a0baad2a00
Closes-Bug: #1294046
"}]
commit_message:
Fix executor requests publishing bug

Make sure request is set to the PENDING state before putting
it into the requests cache to prevent the notify processing
thread get list of waiting requests and publish it before it
is published in the executor thread. So request wouldn't be
published twice.

Change-Id: If6f39a82c5b8554cd429f9ad342021a0baad2a00
Closes-Bug: #1294046

commit_message:
Merge glossary from openstack-manuals

contains these changes:
O'Reilly Edits for the glossary
Use X-as-a-Service
XaaS in Glossary
Update Sahara (ex. Savanna) glossary term
Adds LBaaS overview to Networking intro
Lowercase compute node
Change command line to command-line
Typos in doc/glossary/glossary-terms.xml
Update glossary

WIP: test model migrations

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/24/69124/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pprintfrom alembic.migration import MigrationContext from alembic.autogenerate import compare_metadatafrom nova.db.sqlalchemy import models from nova.db.sqlalchemy import migration from nova.db.sqlalchemy import migrate_repofrom nova.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy import sessionclass TestModelsMigrationsSync(test.TestCase): metadata = models.BASE.metadata def _cleanup(self): meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData(bind=self.engine) meta.reflect() meta.drop_all() self.metadata.drop_all(bind=self.engine) def setUp(self): super(TestModelsMigrationsSync, self).setUp() session.cleanup() self.flags( connection=('postgresql://openstack_citest:openstack_citest@' 'localhost/openstack_citest'), group='database' ) self.engine = session.get_engine() self.addCleanup(session.cleanup) self.addCleanup(self._cleanup) def test_models_sync(self): migration.db_sync() with self.engine.connect() as conn: mc = MigrationContext.configure(conn) diff = compare_metadata(mc, self.metadata) if diff: msg = pprint.pformat(diff, indent=2, width=20) self.fail( "Models and migration scripts aren't in sync:\n%s" % msg)

commit_message:
volume/rbd: Re-enable conditional for string parameters

- According the Michael comments on review¹, the conditional statements
  was re-added (in order to not pass « False » in ini config file).
- Fix spec/defines/* warnings (Space interpreted as grouped expression)

¹https://review.openstack.org/#/c/73892/2/manifests/backend/rbd.pp

(cherry picked from commit 94940882f542c701ab6de27ddd0e51857707fc2b)

Conflicts:
	manifests/volume/rbd.pp

Change-Id: I036ea1bf9dd0c6941d7f02038b39a7f293d68ffe

commit_message:
multi rbd: add opts, deprecate glance_api_version

- Add all cinder rbd params (multi-backends)
- Update documentation/tests
- Deprecate glance_api_version to avoid duplicate definition
  with cinder::glance class.
  (use glance_api_version of cinder::glance class instead.)

(cherry picked from commit dda201af2aa9f4fdca1b46bbeeeea6821ba6b637)

Change-Id: I237ea1ae7a9a1a67272b4ec705d832daef1bc5c7

commit_message:
Add support for VMDK driver

The patch adds support for VMware vmdk cinder driver. It also
supports configuring the driver for multi-backend scenarios.

implements blueprint support-vmdk-driver

(cherry picked from commit 14be6892554ab1c4df6144a0c782bad6b8c9cfec)

Conflicts:
	manifests/volume/vmdk.pp
	spec/classes/cinder_volume_vmdk_spec.rb

Change-Id: Ida0303ac55ab2af5cff9db8fcfcc36d46440c2e2

commit_message:
workaround pypy in requirements

pypy is blocking all requirements merge at the moment, which is
problematic as we've got some changes that should land prior to
icehouse. Implement the work around that fungi posted to IRC.

Looks like it's needed in stable/havana to disable trove.

Co-Authored-By: Sean Dague <sean.dague@samsung.com>
Related-Bug: #1290562
Change-Id: I973e71f96903f687c1e3b6c00db93949d5b88d2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/09/81209/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # work around until pypy vs. setuptools issue in bug 1290562 is fixed [testenv:pypy] deps = setuptools<3.2 -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt

Make rbd.libvirt_info parent class compatible

https://review.openstack.org/32379

commit_message:
Add api tests for load balancer's VIPs and health monitors

Add the following tests:

    1. Create a VIP from an admin user for a tenant other than its own
    2. Update a VIP's description and confirm with a show
    3. Create a VIP specifying address and confirm with list or show
    4. Update a VIP session persistence and confirm with show
    5. Update a VIP connection_limit to other value different than -1 and confirm with show
    6. Update the admin_state_up of a VIP to false and confirm with show
    7. Create a health monitor from an admin user for a tenant id other than its own
    8. Create a health monitor with type HTTP
    9. Update http_method (to POST), url_path (to something other than /) and expected_codes

Change-Id: I2ae2e970cf59ddd10b46e8ae5e4b11d7b5aa6726

commit_message:
Fix start_with_acquired_lock - pass kwargs to func

This method of ThreadGroupManager was not passing kwargs
to the function to be started.

Closes-Bug: #1288627
Change-Id: Icaaa012bcc65c67f3e8ecc2878dee2a78121e357

commit_message:
Add test to rescope token using v2

This adds a test that shows that an unscoped token can be used to
get a scoped token using the identity v2 API.

Change-Id: Ibb6da68d5be2f46f27eb23fbbb7e6e282b026556
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/84/80784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @attr(type='gate') def test_rescope_token(self): """An unscoped token can be requested, that token can be used to request a scoped token.""" # Create a user. user_name = data_utils.rand_name(name='user-') user_password = data_utils.rand_name(name='pass-') tenant_id = None # No default tenant so will get unscoped token. email = '' resp, user = self.client.create_user(user_name, user_password, tenant_id, email) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.data.users.append(user) # Create a tenant. tenant_name = data_utils.rand_name(name='tenant-') resp, tenant = self.client.create_tenant(tenant_name) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.data.tenants.append(tenant) # Create a role role_name = data_utils.rand_name(name='role-') resp, role = self.client.create_role(role_name) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.data.roles.append(role) # Grant the user the role on the tenant. resp, _ = self.client.assign_user_role(tenant['id'], user['id'], role['id']) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) # Get an unscoped token. rsp, body = self.token_client.auth(user_name, user_password) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) token_id = body['token']['id'] # Use the unscoped token to get a scoped token. rsp, body = self.token_client.auth_token(token_id, tenant=tenant_name) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status)

commit_message:
Fix incorrect indent in ceilometer glance section

The second command in step 1 has incorrect indentation, should be
fixed.

- Remove flow REVERTING state. Now flow can be running and reverting simultaneously.
  Until flow isn't finished it is in RUNNING state.

- Add RETRYING state for the retry contorller.

- Implement smart revertion and flow retries and retries resumption.

- Default retry controllers: Times, ForEach and ParameterizedForEach.

- Example and unit tests.

commit_message:
Flow smart revert with retry controller

- Remove flow REVERTING state. Now flow can be running and reverting simultaneously.
  Until flow isn't finished it is in RUNNING state.

- Add RETRYING state for the retry controller.

- Implement smart revertion and flow retries and retries resumption.

- Default retry controllers: Times, ForEach and ParameterizedForEach.

- Example and unit tests.

Implements: blueprint subgraph-execution
Implements: blueprint reversion-strategies
Implements: blueprint smart-revert

Change-Id: Ifa600bcad1edf2910f02ac36783cd458afbd880c

added_lines: from taskflow import exceptionsfrom taskflow.utils import async_utils# Execution and reversion events. EXECUTED = 'executed' REVERTED = 'reverted' def change_state(self, retry, state, result=None): if not self.change_state(retry, states.RUNNING): raise exceptions.InvalidState( "Retry controller can't be executed because " "it is in invalid stated.") self.change_state(retry, states.FAILURE, result=result) else: self.change_state(retry, states.SUCCESS, result=result) return async_utils.make_completed_future((retry, EXECUTED, result)) if not self.change_state(retry, states.REVERTING): raise exceptions.InvalidState( "Retry controller can't be reverted because " "it is in invalid stated.") result = retry.revert(**kwargs) except Exception: result = misc.Failure() self.change_state(retry, states.FAILURE) else: self.change_state(retry, states.REVERTED) return async_utils.make_completed_future((retry, REVERTED, result)) def on_failure(self, retry, last_failure): self._storage.save_retry_failure(retry.name, last_failure) kwargs = self._get_retry_args(retry) return retry.on_failure(**kwargs)
deleted_lines: def _change_state(self, retry, state, result=None): if not self._change_state(retry, states.RUNNING): return self._change_state(retry, states.FAILURE, result=result) else: self._change_state(retry, states.SUCCESS, result=result) if not self._change_state(retry, states.REVERTING): return retry.revert(**kwargs) except Exception: self._change_state(retry, states.FAILURE) else: self._change_state(retry, states.REVERTED)

commit_message:
Remove base.Scenario.register()

Change the way of loading module "'rally.benchmark.scenarios".
Let python load 'rally.benchmark.scenarios' automate, when module "benchmark" been import.

Change-Id: I48986a9692678fb9ef2d413c0004880ae314dd58

commit_message:
Support endpoint type in CLI tests

This patch reads the endpoint_type parameter of the various option
groups of Tempest and passes it as the --(os-)endpoint-type parameter
of the Openstack CLI clients. This allows Tempest to be run in several
network configuration where, for instance, the publicURL is not directly
reachable.

Change-Id: I87f874b9c3fd4fd15907dc933c1ebb62ad4e6e4b

commit_message:
Add draft for API calls for catalog feature

Partly-Implements blueprint murano-repository-api-v2
Change-Id: Id0d691ec94f4a57583260b88e9b1173c9cc5a5b6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/17/79917/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging from muranoapi.db.catalog import Packages from muranoapi.common import wsgi from muranoapi.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ from muranoapi.openstack.common import exception log = logging.getLogger(__name__) MUTABLE_PARAMS = ('tags', 'name', 'description') SUPPORTED_FILTERS = ('order_by', 'category', 'page_number', 'page_size', 'type', 'class', 'category', 'owned') class Controller(object): """ WSGI controller for application catalog resource in Murano v1 API The images resource API is a RESTful web service for image data. The API is as follows:: GET /catalog/packages({?page_number?page_size?order_by?type?category? -- allows to list packages and search though catalog POST /catalog/packages -- allows to upload new application packages GET /catalog/packages/{id} -- retrieve a Package PATCH /catalog/packages/{id} -- allows to edit mutable fields (tags, name, description) GET catalog/packages/{id}/download -- get package with application definition GET /catalog/packages/{id}/ui -- retrieve UI definition for an application GET /catalog/packages/{id}/logo -- Retrieve application logo which described in a package with provided id GET /catalog/packages/categories -- retrieve list of all available application categories """ def _check_for_mutable(self, params): for item in params: if item not in MUTABLE_PARAMS: raise Exception def _get_search_filters(self, req): filters = {} for param in req.params: if param in MUTABLE_PARAMS: filters[param] = req.params.get(param) else: #TODO(efedorova): raise an exception here pass return filters # /catalog/packages({?page_number?page_size?order_by?type?category}) def search(self, req): """ List all packages or search by supported parameters """ #TODO(efedorova): Add pagination filters = self._get_search_filters(req) packages = Packages.search(filters) return packages def upload(self, req, variables): """ Upload new file archive for the new package together with new metadata about that package """ log.debug(_('Packages:Upload <Body {0}>'.format(variables))) package_meta = Packages.upload(variables) return package_meta def update(self, req, package_id, variables): self._check_for_mutable(variables.keys()) package_meta = Packages.update(variables) return package_meta def get(self, req, package_id): #TODO(efedorova): check package_id exists package_meta = Packages.get(package_id) return package_meta def delete(self, req, package_id): #TODO(efedorova): check package_id exists Packages.delete(package_id) def get_ui(self, req, package_id): #TODO(efedorova): check package_id exists ui_definition = Packages.get_ui_definition(package_id) return {'ui_definition': ui_definition} def get_logo(self, req, package_id): #TODO(efedorova): check package_id exists logo = Packages.get_logo(package_id) #TODO(efedorova): set valid content-type return logo def download(self, req, package_id): #TODO(efedorova): check package_id exists archive = Packages.get_archive(package_id) #TODO(efedorova): set valid content-type return archive def show_categories(self, req): categories = Packages.list_categories() return categories def create_resource(): return wsgi.Resource(Controller())

commit_message:
Fix image service endpoint path

After converging with telemetry and image, the ceilometer meters and
resources for glance do not appear, the logs show that the glance API
URL is incorrect: http://127.0.0.1:9292/v2/v1.

This patch sets the base path to / so ceilometer can talk to glance.

Change-Id: I656e133995b4cbad12540d03c97adf1164b0f4c5
Closes-Bug: #1293688

commit_message:
[bp] Add support for Cinder multi-backend

* Create class cinder::backend.
   Sets DEFAULT/enabled_backends

* Create define cinder::type.
   multip-purpose function to create type and optionally set extened
   information.

* Create define cinder::type_set.
   multi-purpose set function to set extended information.

* Copy rbd, iscsi, and nfs volume providers to support multi-backend
   Now provided as cinder::backend::<driver> to ensure that multi-backend
   aware resource is|[ not] used.

* Add rspec for new parts to ensure expected function.

Blueprint: cinder-volume-multi-backend

(cherry picked from commit 209a5bd36af085cf306cf084ed1af1bf0fc9f41d)

Conflicts:
	README.md

Change-Id: Ia2a92a067be6e785d7ca92c4029372ecf6e02ba7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/70/80070/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'cinder::backend::nfs' do let (:title) {'hippo'} let :params do { :nfs_servers => ['10.10.10.10:/shares', '10.10.10.10:/shares2'], :nfs_mount_options => 'vers=3', :nfs_shares_config => '/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf', :nfs_disk_util => 'du', :nfs_sparsed_volumes => true, :nfs_mount_point_base => '/cinder_mount_point', } end describe 'nfs volume driver' do it 'configures nfs volume driver' do should contain_cinder_config('hippo/volume_backend_name').with( :value => 'hippo') should contain_cinder_config('hippo/volume_driver').with_value( 'cinder.volume.drivers.nfs.NfsDriver') should contain_cinder_config('hippo/nfs_shares_config').with_value( '/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf') should contain_cinder_config('hippo/nfs_mount_options').with_value( 'vers=3') should contain_cinder_config('hippo/nfs_sparsed_volumes').with_value( true) should contain_cinder_config('hippo/nfs_mount_point_base').with_value( '/cinder_mount_point') should contain_cinder_config('hippo/nfs_disk_util').with_value( 'du') should contain_file('/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf').with( :content => "10.10.10.10:/shares\n10.10.10.10:/shares2", :require => 'Package[cinder]', :notify => 'Service[cinder-volume]' ) end end end
